intro: Ipomopsis spicata, commonly known as the spiculate phlox, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its showy, tubular flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has hairy stems and leaves. Its flowers are usually pink to purple in color and attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Ipomopsis spicata is often used in native plant gardens due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits.
